docs.lead_paragraph: An excess of certain hormones may be responsible for heart disease and heart attacks in people who compulsively seek work, those who are impatient and other ''Type A personalities,'' according to a Duke University scientist. Dr. Redford Williams says Type A men, characterized as high-strung, produce high levels of cortisol, adrenaline and noradrenaline while they are mentally solving problems in arithmetic and produce high levels of testosterone while they are undergoing tests of their reaction time. About 12 out of every 1,000 Type A's suffer heart attacks, as against four or five for every 1,000 of the more relaxed, or Type B, personalities, said Dr. Williams, who is a psychiatrist. His tests are meant to help determine what causes that difference and his work is described in the Oct. 29 issue of the magazine Science.
